io.atomix.group

Class SubGroup

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.atomix.group.SubGroup
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Managed<DistributedGroup>, DistributedGroup, Resource<DistributedGroup>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConsistentHashGroup, GroupPartition, PartitionGroup

    public abstract class SubGroup
extends Object
implements DistributedGroup
    Base class for subgroups of DistributedGroup.

    DistributedGroup can be partitioned into subgroups that can be nested to any depth. This allows groups to be partitioned multiple times to facilitate replication algorithms. Subgroups are guaranteed to be consistent across all nodes in a cluster. For example, in a MembershipGroup partitioned into a PartitionGroup with 3 partitions, each GroupPartition will represent the same members on all nodes in the cluster. Changes to groups and subgroups are guaranteed to occur in the same order on all nodes.

    Subgroups inherit a number of attributes of their parent group. When a group is partitioned into a subgroup, the subgroup will inherit the membership list of the parent group but may represent only a subset of those members. Changes in the set of members in a parent group will be immediately reflected in all subgroups. Subgroups inherit the properties, tasks, configuration, and options of the base MembershipGroup.

    Author:

      • writeConsistency

        public WriteConsistency writeConsistency()
        Description copied from interface: Resource
        Returns the configured write consistency level.

        Resource consistency levels are configured via the Resource.with(WriteConsistency) setter. By default, all resources submit commands under the WriteConsistency.ATOMIC consistency level. See the WriteConsistency documentation for information about guarantees provided by specific consistency levels.

        Specified by:
        writeConsistency in interface Resource<DistributedGroup>
        Returns:
        The configured resource consistency level.

      • with

        public DistributedGroup with(WriteConsistency consistency)
        Description copied from interface: Resource
        Sets the write consistency level.

        The configured consistency level specifies how operations on the resource should be handled by the cluster. Consistency levels dictate the order in which reads, writes, and events should be handled by the Atomix cluster and the consistency requirements for completing different types of operations.

        Note that consistency configurations apply only to a single instance of a distributed resource. Two instances of the same resource on the same or different nodes can have different consistency requirements, and the cluster will obey those differences.

        By default, all resource operations are submitted to the cluster with the WriteConsistency.ATOMIC consistency level. Atomic consistency means that the distributed resource will behave as a single object for all instances. Users can decrease the default consistency level, but note that in some cases resource implementations may override the configured WriteConsistency for safety. For instance, a leader election may enforce atomic consistency at all times to ensure no two leaders can be elected at the same time.

        Specified by:
        with in interface Resource<DistributedGroup>
        Parameters:
        consistency - The write consistency level.
        Returns:
        The resource instance.

        public GroupProperties properties()
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns the group properties.

        The returned properties apply to the entire group regardless of whether this instance is a membership group, hash group, partition group, or partitions. Properties can be set and read by any instance of the group, and properties will persist until removed or the group itself is deleted.

        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup

      • hash

        public ConsistentHashGroup hash()
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a consistent hash group.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned hash group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the same event will occur in the returned hash group as well. The hash group will be created with a Murmur2Hasher to hash nodes and values onto a hash ring, and members will be hashed to the ring with 100 virtual nodes. To override default values use the overloaded methods. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("hash-group").get();

   // Create a consistent hash group
   ConsistentHashGroup hashGroup = group.hash();

   // Send a key/value to the appropriate member of the group
   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   hashGroup.member(key).connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
        The returned hash group is static and is guaranteed to always be the same ConsistentHashGroup instance.
        Specified by:
        hash in interface DistributedGroup
        Returns:
        A consistent hash group.

      • hash

        public ConsistentHashGroup hash(Hasher hasher)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a consistent hash group.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned hash group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the same event will occur in the returned hash group as well. The hash group will be created with 100 virtual nodes per member. To override default values use the overloaded methods. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("hash-group").get();

   // Create a consistent hash group
   ConsistentHashGroup hashGroup = group.hash(new StringHasher());

   // Send a key/value to the appropriate member of the group
   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   hashGroup.member(key).connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
        The returned hash group is static and is guaranteed to always be the same ConsistentHashGroup instance given the same arguments.
        Specified by:
        hash in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        hasher - The hasher with which to hash values in the group.
        Returns:
        A consistent hash group.

      • hash

        public ConsistentHashGroup hash(int virtualNodes)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a consistent hash group.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned hash group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the same event will occur in the returned hash group as well. The hash group will be created with the Murmur2Hasher for hashing nodes and values onto the hash ring. To override default values use the overloaded methods. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("hash-group").get();

   // Create a consistent hash group
   ConsistentHashGroup hashGroup = group.hash(200);

   // Send a key/value to the appropriate member of the group
   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   hashGroup.member(key).connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
        The returned hash group is static and is guaranteed to always be the same ConsistentHashGroup instance given the same arguments.
        Specified by:
        hash in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        virtualNodes - The number of virtual nodes per member of the group.
        Returns:
        A new consistent hash group.

      • hash

        public ConsistentHashGroup hash(Hasher hasher,
                                int virtualNodes)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a consistent hash group.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned hash group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the same event will occur in the returned hash group as well. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("hash-group").get();

   // Create a consistent hash group
   ConsistentHashGroup hashGroup = group.hash(new StringHasher(), 200);

   // Send a key/value to the appropriate member of the group
   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   hashGroup.member(key).connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
        The returned hash group is static and is guaranteed to always be the same ConsistentHashGroup instance given the same arguments.
        Specified by:
        hash in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        hasher - The hasher with which to hash values in the group.
        virtualNodes - The number of virtual nodes per member of the group.
        Returns:
        A new consistent hash group.

      • partition

        public PartitionGroup partition(int partitions)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a partition group.

        The returned group will be configured with a replicationFactor of 1, indicating that each partition may consist of up to one member. The group will be configured to use the HashPartitioner to hash values to partitions.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned partition group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the change will be reflected in the PartitionGroup. However, the members will be partitioned into the given number of partitions. Each partition within the group will represent some subset of the members of the group. Members are partitioned by hashing them onto a ring and hashing partitions to points on the same ring. Once hashed to a point on the ring, the n members following that point will become members of the partition. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("partition-group").get();

   // Partition the group into three partitions
   PartitionGroup partitions = group.partition(3);

   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   // Hash the key to a partition and send a key/value pair
   partitions.partitions().get(key).members().forEach(member -> {
     member.connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
   });
        Each GroupPartition within the partition group is its own unique group of members. Leaders can be elected among the partition members and tasks can be submitted to the partition members independently of the parent PartitionGroup or this group. GroupProperties, however, are shared among all DistributedGroup instances.

        The returned PartitionGroup is static and is guaranteed to always be the same instance given the same arguments.

        Specified by:
        partition in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        partitions - The number of partitions in the group.
        Returns:
        A partition group.

      • partition

        public PartitionGroup partition(int partitions,
                                int replicationFactor)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a partition group.

        The replicationFactor indicates the number of members that should be included in each partition. Members of this group will be mapped to partitions in the returned PartitionGroup, and when membership changes occur in this group members will be repartitioned as necessary. The group will be configured to use the HashPartitioner to hash values to partitions of the group.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned partition group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the change will be reflected in the PartitionGroup. However, the members will be partitioned into the given number of partitions. Each partition within the group will represent some subset of the members of the group. Members are partitioned by hashing them onto a ring and hashing partitions to points on the same ring. Once hashed to a point on the ring, the n members following that point will become members of the partition. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("partition-group").get();

   // Partition the group into three partitions
   PartitionGroup partitions = group.partition(3, 3);

   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   // Hash the key to a partition and send a key/value pair
   partitions.partitions().get(key).members().forEach(member -> {
     member.connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
   });
        Each GroupPartition within the partition group is its own unique group of members. Leaders can be elected among the partition members and tasks can be submitted to the partition members independently of the parent PartitionGroup or this group. GroupProperties, however, are shared among all DistributedGroup instances.

        The returned PartitionGroup is static and is guaranteed to always be the same instance given the same arguments.

        Specified by:
        partition in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        partitions - The number of partitions in the group.
        replicationFactor - The replication factor per partition.
        Returns:
        A partition group.

      • partition

        public PartitionGroup partition(int partitions,
                                GroupPartitioner partitioner)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a partition group.

        The GroupPartitioner will be used to map values to partitions of the group. The returned group will be configured with a replicationFactor of 1, indicating that each partition may consist of up to one member.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned partition group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the change will be reflected in the PartitionGroup. However, the members will be partitioned into the given number of partitions. Each partition within the group will represent some subset of the members of the group. Members are partitioned by hashing them onto a ring and hashing partitions to points on the same ring. Once hashed to a point on the ring, the n members following that point will become members of the partition. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("partition-group").get();

   // Partition the group into three partitions
   PartitionGroup partitions = group.partition(3, new RoundRobinPartitioner());

   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   // Hash the key to a partition and send a key/value pair
   partitions.partitions().get(key).members().forEach(member -> {
     member.connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
   });
        Each GroupPartition within the partition group is its own unique group of members. Leaders can be elected among the partition members and tasks can be submitted to the partition members independently of the parent PartitionGroup or this group. GroupProperties, however, are shared among all DistributedGroup instances.

        The returned PartitionGroup is static and is guaranteed to always be the same instance given the same arguments.

        Specified by:
        partition in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        partitions - The number of partitions in the group.
        partitioner - The group partitioner.
        Returns:
        A partition group.

      • partition

        public PartitionGroup partition(int partitions,
                                int replicationFactor,
                                GroupPartitioner partitioner)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Returns a partition group.

        The replicationFactor indicates the number of members that should be included in each partition. Members of this group will be mapped to partitions in the returned PartitionGroup, and when membership changes occur in this group members will be repartitioned as necessary. The provided GroupPartitioner will be used to map values to partitions.

        The DistributedGroup.members() in the returned partition group will mirror the members of this group. When a member is added to or removed from this group, the change will be reflected in the PartitionGroup. However, the members will be partitioned into the given number of partitions. Each partition within the group will represent some subset of the members of the group. Members are partitioned by hashing them onto a ring and hashing partitions to points on the same ring. Once hashed to a point on the ring, the n members following that point will become members of the partition. 

           
   // Create a new distributed group
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("partition-group").get();

   // Partition the group into three partitions
   PartitionGroup partitions = group.partition(3, 3, new RoundRobinPartitioner());

   Object key = "foo";
   Object value = "Hello world!";
   // Hash the key to a partition and send a key/value pair
   partitions.partitions().get(key).members().forEach(member -> {
     member.connection().send("set", new KeyValue(key, value));
   });
        Each GroupPartition within the partition group is its own unique group of members. Leaders can be elected among the partition members and tasks can be submitted to the partition members independently of the parent PartitionGroup or this group. GroupProperties, however, are shared among all DistributedGroup instances.

        The returned PartitionGroup is static and is guaranteed to always be the same instance given the same arguments.

        Specified by:
        partition in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        partitions - The number of partitions in the group.
        replicationFactor - The replication factor per partition.
        partitioner - The group partitioner.
        Returns:
        A partition group.

      • join

        public CompletableFuture<LocalGroupMember> join()
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Joins the instance to the membership group.

        When this instance joins the membership group, the membership lists of this and all other instances in the group are guaranteed to be updated before the CompletableFuture returned by this method is completed. Once this instance has joined the group, the returned future will be completed with the GroupMember instance for this member.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.join() method to block the calling thread: 

           
   group.join().join();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the lock is acquired in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   group.join().thenAccept(thisMember -> System.out.println("This member is: " + thisMember.id()));
        Specified by:
        join in interface DistributedGroup
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the member has joined.

      • join

        public CompletableFuture<LocalGroupMember> join(String memberId)
        Description copied from interface: DistributedGroup
        Joins the instance to the membership group with a user-provided member ID.

        When this instance joins the membership group, the membership lists of this and all other instances in the group are guaranteed to be updated before the CompletableFuture returned by this method is completed. Once this instance has joined the group, the returned future will be completed with the GroupMember instance for this member.

        This method returns a CompletableFuture which can be used to block until the operation completes or to be notified in a separate thread once the operation completes. To block until the operation completes, use the CompletableFuture.join() method to block the calling thread: 

           
   group.join().join();
        Alternatively, to execute the operation asynchronous and be notified once the lock is acquired in a different thread, use one of the many completable future callbacks: 
           
   group.join().thenAccept(thisMember -> System.out.println("This member is: " + thisMember.id()));
        Specified by:
        join in interface DistributedGroup
        Parameters:
        memberId - The unique member ID to assign to the member.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the member has joined.

        public CompletableFuture<Void> close()
        Description copied from interface: Resource
        Closes the resource.

        Once the resource is closed, the resource will be transitioned to the Resource.State.CLOSED state and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed. Thereafter, attempts to operate on the resource will fail.

        Specified by:
